Patch Set 39:

(3 comments)
This change needs some tests
(marking unresolved)
Done
Please strip the `wip: ` prefix if this change is no-longer work-in-progress.
Done. Please check, thank you.
Done
Please try to say something more descriptive here. Can you add some context for needing the message, and perhaps described its serialised layout?
Done. Please check, thank you.
Done
Hi Lora, I have a couple of comments inline that should be addressed.
I prefer we don't use bullet-lists here. Please drop them and leave the discussion as a regular paragraph.
I've removed the bullet-lists description. Please check, thank you.
Hi Lora, I have one minor request inline, but can you also please add tests for the new functionality?
Thanks for addressing the concerns so far, however this change still needs tests.
This should be unnecessary as the documentation is about OEM PLDM messages, not libpldm API functions.
Done
See the comments on the previous patch about what should be listed here.
I removed unnecessary "List of read file IO messages" title content.
Done
The read response needs actual data, right? Either the metadata, or the data requested?
I have re-modified the encode function. Please help to review, thank you.
There's still no data?
Added. Please check, thank you.
Hi Lora, I have some concerns with this still.
Shouldn't there be some data as well?
Data buffer has been added. Please check, thank you.
Why a request message when we're encoding a response?

Originally I wanted to put the handle and option in req_msg into responseMsg.
Put struct pldm_oem_meta_file_io_read_resp pointer instead.
Please check, thank you.
This is the wrong type? We're dealing with a response, right?

Has been modified to put in struct pldm_oem_meta_file_io_read_resp pointer.
Please check, thank you.
No, please use `pldm_msgbuf_insert()`.
Done. Please check, thank you.

Add encode response test case.
pre-submit script execution result：Pass
Hi Lora, can you please rebase this series? I've just submitted some changes to the msgbuf APIs that you might need to account for.
Done. Please help to check, thank you.

Rebase main and fix the conflicts.
Please help to review, thank you.
Hi Lora, I've reworked the tests and code a bit to align with some new thoughts I have on removing all use of `reinterpret_cast<>()`. I'll do a follow-up review of the actual functionality soon.
OK. Thank you for your reply

Hi Andrew：
I have some changes that I need to confirm with you.
Done
We should adda `size_t version` field above here when you introduced this in the previous patch. See the comment below about extensible commands.
I will add a field for size_t version.
Done. Please check, thank you.
Sorry, yep, that looks good!
Done. Please check, thank you.
I will add this check.
Done. Please check, thank you.
I will add this check.
Done. Please check, thank you.
Can we please keep the variable declarations and definitions at the top of the function, before any code?
I will move these definitions to the top of the function.
Done. Please check, thank you.
Don't need to check the return value here as we're not extracting the length, it's provided by the caller.
I will remove this check.
Done. Please check, thank you.
We should only do this if we're returning data. If the response is for an attribute read we should explicitly insert the fields.

As suggested I should make the following changes：
1. Use option to confirm whether you want to insert the read result into attr (Option = PLDM_OEM_META_FILE_IO_READ_ATTR) or info (Option = PLDM_OEM_META_FILE_IO_READ_DATA).
2. If the option is PLDM_OEM_META_FILE_IO_READ_DATA, the file data is inserted into data according to length.
Sounds good. I think we also want to include the metadata for `*_READ_DATA` as well, right?
We will not need to add another "metadata" parameter, and will put the read data into the data of struct pldm_oem_meta_file_io_read_resp.
Sorry, I need a moment to confirm why there is an error message of "killed by signal 6 SIGABRT".
Solved.

Hi Andrew：
Modify with the suggestions. Please help to review, thank you.
Hi Lora, a few more comments that I also hope are straight-forward to address.
Can we call this `data`?
Done. Please help to review, thank you.
Done. Please help to review, thank you.
This should be `size_t`.
Done. Please help to review, thank you.
`size_t`.
Done. Please help to review, thank you.

The idiomatic approach to passing object sizes is to pass them after the corresponding pointer argument. So to match conventions, this should be:

```
int encode_oem_meta_file_io_read_resp(uint8_t instance_id, struct pldm_oem_meta_file_io_read_resp *resp, size_t resp_len, struct pldm_msg *msg, size_t payload_length);
```

And with that, you'll need to fix the ordering in the doxygen.
Done. Please help to review, thank you.
`size_t` please.
After modification, compare_length parameter is no longer needed, so delete this parameter.

This should be `return -EPROTO;` - it's not that the parameter values are invalid from a (C) language perspective, rather the definition for the message isn't one that the current implementation of libpldm recognises (though the definition of the message may expand in the future).
The modified line 209 has been changed to -EPROTO.
The modified line 209 has been changed to -EPROTO.
I don't think we need this test as it's handled by the msgbuf implementation.
Removed. Please help to review, thank you.
No, this argument must reflect the size of the buffer holding the data at `resp->data`. This should be `resp_len - sizeof(*resp)`.
Done. Please help to review, thank you.

I think this should rather be `pldm_msgbuf_destroy(buf)` - it's fine if the caller over-allocates the memory for `responseMsg`. Note that this is different to the `decode_*()` implementations, where the caller should know exactly how much data they read off the transport. We absolutely should use `pldm_msgbuf_destroy_consumed(buf)` in the `decode_*()` cases, but not in the `encode_*()` cases.
Done. Please help to review, thank you.
Hi Andrew：Modifications have been made according to the suggestions. Please help to review. Thank you.
